most of what you say in this video is not correct or at most misleading. the electrons in graphene do not move close to the speed of light at all. in fact they move 300 times slower. they effectively behave as a relativistic particle due to the symmetry of the lattice. the high mobility of the electrons is not because of the lack of defects in graphene but because of an effect called Klein tunneling. graphene also does not conduct better than copper. while the electrons in graphene are very mobile, the density of electrons is very small leading to much smaller currents. the whole elephant on a pencil is also nonsense. this is only true if the strength of graphene is extrapolated to the thickness of a piece of saran wrap.

There's something bothering me in this video. You said that electrons goes "fast" through this conductor, when they should go slower than any tortoise can be - their speed is about 3x10^-4 meters per second at 3 ampére in an standard copper wire, which means it would take almost 3 hours (2 hours and 47 minutes) to the electrons travel 3 meters, something you can do with 2 or 3 steps in few seconds!!! I mean, it is a huge difference from 3x10^-4 to fractions of 3x10^8, something less than 10^12 but around that, which represent the difference between graphene and a standard copper wire in terms of electron drift velocity. I believe the electric impulse is indeed that fast, but electric impulse and electron drift velocity are two different things. Not understanding that difference makes us believe that when we turn the light on, a single electron from the wire on the switch travels through the wire to the light bulb in a fraction of second, when truly what happens is that the electrons are "pushing" each other forward in a stream due to a difference in potential, so the electron that really turns the light on is the one in the wire right next to the light bulb.

In graphene and graphite layers, there are 3 strong sigma bonds in the plane of the layer and 1 weak metallic-style delocalised "glue" bond.  in graphene, all the layers are in the same plane, meaning that all of the strong bonds stick strongly in one direction; in graphite the layers are jumbled up in different planes so that the graphite is uniformly strong but not exceptionally strong in any given direction due to the easy to break bonds between layers.
because the binding between atoms of different layers are extremely weak compared to the bindings in between the atoms of the same layer

Because while a layer is very strong, the bond between each layer is not.

Consider a sheet of paper. It hold itself together and if you grab a corner the rest will follow. Now you stack a bunch of sheet of paper together. If you kick the pile of paper it will shatter into a bunch of individual sheets of paper.

This is not a perfect analogy but it should be enough to illustrate why graphite (pile of paper) is weak while graphene (single sheet) is stronger.

the layers are only held together by weak intermolecular forces, so the layers arent very attracted to each other. the single layers are very strong, it's just the forces between THEM that make it so easy to break.

@Trisscarro Stacking multiple layers of graphene would indeed create graphite again! Depending on how much you know of intermolecular forces, it can be quite easy to explain. Every layer of graphite is comprised of a carbon atom with 3 carbon atoms σ-bonded in a planar formation. Since the valency of carbon is 4 then every carbon atom then forms π-bonds perpendicular to itself. If you remove these π-bonds then each atom uses a bit more energy for its σ-bonds to make them stronger.

@Trisscarro Each layer of graphene is strong in that way. It's not that the multiple layers are weaker than the single one, but simply that they're held together weakly. Imagine taking steel sheets and then scotch taping them together. One sheet is equivalent to one sheet of graphene. Stacks of them creates the mineral graphite. the steel sheets themselves are very strong, but the scotch tape that holds them together is weak.

@Trisscarro hi! It has everything to do with the carbon lattice of graphene. The carbons are bonded together in such a way that make it extremely orderly - which is why it has some of those unique properties. They're also bonded covalently, which is a stronger chemical bond than an ionic bond.

When you layer graphene on top of each other to create graphite, the layers are held together by weak van der waals forces, which is why it's able to slip off so easily.
